data.title: What is bone calcification?
data.normalized_content: Bone calcification or bone calcification is the accumulation of Calcium in body tissue, often occurring during the bone formation process. This condition can be a pathology or a natural sign of aging depending on each specific case. Calcified bones are the result of the body protecting itself, or in other words, a natural response to injury, infection and other autoimmune disorders. (1) In general, calcified bones are a common form of degeneration, greatly affecting mobility and daily activities. If treatment is not carried out early, the condition can progress with many other serious complications, even irreversible. Among them, the two most common forms of bone calcification include: Cervical spine calcification The cervical spine is responsible for the activities of rotation, supination, bending, bending and balancing the head. Bone calcification occurs here mainly due to incorrect lying or sitting posture or injury. Calcification of the lumbar spine The lumbar spine is very susceptible to calcification due to high pressure from body weight and damage caused by daily movements (walking, sitting, lying, carrying...). This condition often occurs commonly after the age of 40. In addition, young people who have the habit of sitting a lot and being sedentary are also at risk group.

data.title: signs of bone calcification
data.normalized_content: Depending on the location of formation, bone calcification will appear with different symptoms, specifically as follows: Bone calcification appears inside the joint or deep in the tissue: It will be very difficult for the patient to notice obvious symptoms. . Bone calcification forms near the skin: Small bumps appear on the skin surface. Bone calcification develops in the shoulder: It is difficult for the arm to move normally due to pain, and the range of motion is limited. Spinal calcification: Spinal nerves are compressed, causing numbness or pain in the arms, legs or other areas of the body. If the spines grow deep inside, it can lead to spinal stenosis, making it difficult to stand upright and walk. Calcification develops in the knee: The patient finds it difficult to perform normal movements such as moving up and down stairs, getting in and out of the car... Calcification develops in the heel: The patient finds it difficult when touching the ground or walking. Calcification develops in the cervical spine: This condition causes arteries or veins to be compressed, blood flow to the brain is limited, and the trachea can also be pressed on, causing difficulty swallowing.

data.title: causes of bone calcification | bone calcification
data.normalized_content: Bone calcification comes from a number of main causes as follows: (2) Infection. Calcium metabolism disorder. Genetic or autoimmune disorders that affect the skeletal system or connective tissues. Persistent inflammation causes tissue damage and stimulates the body to release proteins that bind calcium to form hard blocks. Stressed or damaged bones: In this case, Calcium will move through the bloodstream to the injured area to perform repair, leading to calcium accumulation, which gradually hardens when not detected and treated promptly. time. Many misconceptions still believe that the habit of eating a lot of calcium is one of the causes of bone calcification. However, studies have not found a link between these two factors. Risk factors Women over 40 years old. People with a sedentary lifestyle cause calcium to accumulate in soft tissues instead of being sent to the necessary places to maintain bone strength. Aging. Tendons are damaged. Genetic. Abnormal activity of the thyroid gland. Certain substances are produced by the body to fight inflammation. Metabolic diseases, including diabetes.

data.title: Bone calcification complications may occur
data.normalized_content: Bone calcification becomes a concern when the location, shape or size causes tissue damage. Some typical complications can be mentioned as follows: Calcification hardens, blockage of blood vessels in the heart, brain, and kidneys. Gradual calcification leads to the formation of spurs and bone spurs in the paravertebral ligaments. When the size is too large, they will begin to compress the nerves, leading to muscle weakness and even loss of motor function in the long term. Irritation of surrounding tissues, leading to inflammation. Some cases of calcification spread to the shoulders, arms, and legs when nerves are compressed or damaged, causing severe pain.

data.title: diagnostic methods | bone calcification
data.normalized_content: For bone calcification, the doctor will initially conduct a physical examination and ask a number of questions related to the location of pain, pain level and specific symptoms. Then, diagnostic methods can be performed to ensure the most accurate conclusion, including: (3) X-ray: The X-ray method will use electromagnetic radiation to collect Get images of bones, organs inside the body and excess Calcium accumulated on bones. Ultrasound: Ultrasound may be prescribed to detect small calcium deposits that cannot be identified by X-ray methods. Biopsy: In some cases, your doctor may request a biopsy, specifically collecting a tissue sample and sending it to a laboratory to detect cancer (if any).

data.title: How to treat bone calcification
data.normalized_content: Bone calcification cannot be cured completely, the main measures are aimed at reducing pain. For this condition, depending on the severity, the doctor may prescribe some treatments as follows: (4) Perform physical therapy, exercise: This is the basic solution , focusing on improving symptoms, slowing down the process of bone degeneration and calcification. At the same time, exercises also have the effect of relaxing muscle tendons, helping to significantly reduce common pain symptoms. However, the implementation process requires perseverance and the right method to ensure high efficiency. Infrared ray treatment: In some cases, the doctor will prescribe infrared ray treatment, specifically shining a light on the calcified bone area to reduce pain. The pain relief effect will not last long but can temporarily improve uncomfortable symptoms, helping patients limit their dependence on medication. Using over-the-counter pain relievers (Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen, Naproxen sodium...): This is a temporary pain relief method and does not have a complete treatment effect. However, patients should not use it for a long time to avoid affecting their stomach and health. In most cases, this method is only indicated when other treatments are ineffective. In addition, patients should absolutely follow the doctor's instructions to avoid unwanted side effects. Surgery: If all medical treatments do not bring any improvement, your doctor may prescribe surgery. For bone calcification, no matter what treatment method is used, the doctor will ask the patient to have regular follow-up examinations to check for potential complications. This will help promptly control other serious problems, ensuring the most favorable treatment and recovery process.

data.title: Measures to prevent bone calcification | bone calcification
data.normalized_content: Bone calcification can be proactively prevented early on with some useful solutions as follows: Carry out regular health examinations to check the amount of Calcium in the bones and detect abnormalities related to the condition. bone calcification (if any). Some medications or therapies can affect the body's ability to metabolize calcium, such as: blood pressure regulators, cholesterol, hormone replacement therapy... Therefore, patients should discuss carefully. consult your doctor before use to avoid unwanted problems. Quit the habit of smoking to avoid the risk of calcification in bones, heart and arteries. Build a healthy diet, ensuring to provide the necessary amount of Calcium every day for the body with the following foods: seeds (sesame, chia seeds...), cheese, yogurt, almonds, beans... Maintain a regular exercise routine every day to keep bones strong, improve blood circulation, and help the body transport Calcium to where it is needed instead of accumulating it in soft tissues.
